lines.text: But to me the most important thing to know about an assassination is not who fired a shot - but who paid for the bullet!
A book is a lovely thing, a garden stocked with beautiful flowers, a magic carpet on which to fly away to unknown climes.
Peterson was always too ingenious; and ingenuity is never a substitute for intelligence.

[after they inquire about Dimitrios in the nightclub]
Get out!
Sit down! Do you think I want a scene in here?

[Sarcastically]
If you can explain how I can leave without standing up, I'd be grateful.

[to Dimitrios after he has shot Peters]
He was my friend... No, he wasn't my friend, but he was a nice man!

[With sarcasm to Peters]
Oh, you're knocking now, sir. Excellent! Excellent!
Mr. Leyden, can I use your paper?

[Sarcastically]
Why not? You've used everything else!

[Repeated with small variations throughout the story]
How little kindness there is in the world today!

[to Leyden]
I've known many men, but I've only been afraid of one of them... Dimitrios.

[realizing he's being duped and blackmailed]
You dirty spy!

[sardonically, as he has being led away by police]
You wanted to write a book. Send me a copy. I'll have lots of time to read it.

[after Dimitrios has left]
What did you think of him?
It was Dimitrios all right - ruthless and primitive. I was afraid of him.
